...and yeah, it's sad, but when hear your typical American voter talking about why they like or dislike any given candidate, the person's policy positions seem to come up a very small fraction of the time (and it's obvious that a good chunk of the time, the voter in question has no idea what the candidate's policy positions are in the first place).

One of the biggest myths in the U.S. political landscape is that Democrats and Republicans are becoming more "polarized."  Yes, I understand that this is the FACADE they give us in their overt behavior in front of the cameras, but behind closed doors, at least on economic issues, Democrats and Republicans are virtually indistinguishable at this point.  The bottom line is, they both accept massive amounts of money from Wall Street, Corporate America and the military industrial complex which, in turn, all but assures that these are the interests to whom "our" elected officials answer.  For their part, the Republicans have always been this way but the Democrats, who once actually represented regular people, really started going in this direction in earnest during the Clinton years and regular Americans haven't been represented in Washington since (again, at least on economic issues).

+CrashCourse You forgot to mention that various studies have found a link between low intelligence and conservative beliefs (including specifically, low-IQ and prejudice, low-IQ and religiosity, and an inverse relationship between academic achievement and conservative beliefs). When people vote, they are making a statement about themselves. They know that their single vote will probably not matter much in the total election, unless the election turns out to be INCREDIBLY close. So really the act of voting is just way for us to confirm something we like to think about ourselves. Whether that thing is "I am a conservative" or "I hate the Iraq War" or "I care about poor people" or "I'm a red-blooded church-going American". It's all about a declaration of self.

To me the whole theory on voting by the political scientists seems a bit American biased (yes, I know, the show is mainly based on American politics). Party loyalty seems one of the stupidest reasons to vote for a party and it certainly saddens me if that's how they choose their candidates. Same with the social background. But I guess that is the result of the current bipolarity of American politics where the whole political spectrum is poorly represented.

Personally, I choose my candidates solely on their stands on issues. In my country, many news sites run these massive questionnaires on political candidates. You can then take the same questionnaire and see who you identify with the most. I usually use those and select one of the top three or five candidates, regardless of the party. I only have one rule when it comes to voting, never vote for the Christian Party (because magic has no place in government) and never vote for the Green Party (I'm not anti-environmental, it's just that all their ideas are too detached from real life).

I know this is falling on deaf ears because the script is already wrote and the video probably already in post, but I hope you spend more than just a few token seconds on third parties. People do not have to vote for democrats or republicans.

Argh, I couldn't disagree with you more about issue voting, Craig. I think issue voting is actually one of the biggest problems with the way we do vote. Research into people's voting history glosses over a lot of the legislative quality that influences their voting. Looking at candidates through this lens also fails to consider their thinking process, and how they will react to new issues, or issues that were not at the forefront during the election. When I consider who I am going to vote for, I want to know not what they think but how they think. What is there process for arriving at a decision? How do they select their advisers? What kind of experience do they have in positions that require critical thinking and decision making?
